did.unittitle: Lyman H. and Elizabeth Eaton Butterfield papers

bioghist.p: Lyman Henry Butterfield (1909-1982) was an historical editor. He worked as a professor of English and American History at Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and was the director of the Institute of Early American History and Culture at Williamsburg from 1951 to 1954. He is best known as the editor of the papers of Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Rush, and as the editor in chief of The Adams Papers. He was also a member of the board of editors of the New England Quarterly from 1956 to 1982. Elizabeth Eaton Butterfield was a graduate of Bryn Mawr College. She and Lyman Butterfield married in 1935. In the mid-1950s, she and other Bryn Mawr alumnae in the Boston area founded the Bryn Mawr Book Store in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The store grew out of a series of annual book sales held to fund scholarships to area students attending Bryn Mawr.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional and personal papers of Lyman H. and Elizabeth Eaton Butterfield. The Lyman H. Butterfield materials in this collection include personal and professional correspondence, childhood letters, family photographs and keepsakes. Materials related to Elizabeth Butterfield include personal and professional correspondence, financial records, appointment books, journals and notebooks.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
